title: Honoring President Stuart Steiner upon the occasion of his retirement after over 40 years of distinguished service to Genesee Community College
fulltext:
LEGISLATIVE  RESOLUTION honoring President Stuart Steiner upon the occa-
sion of his retirement after over 40 years of distinguished  service  to
Genesee Community College

WHEREAS,  It  is  the  intent  of this Legislative Body to recognize and
honor  the  significant  milestones  in  the  distinguished  careers  of
esteemed residents of this noble Empire State; and
  WHEREAS,  Attendant  to  such concern, and in full accordance with its
long-standing traditions, this Legislative Body is justly proud to honor
President Stuart Steiner upon the occasion of his retirement after  over
four  decades of service and commitment to Genesee Community College; he
served 36 of those years as the College's president, the  second-longest
serving president of a community college in the Nation; and
  WHEREAS, President Steiner is the third president of Genesee Community
College  and  has  been  with  the college since it was founded in 1967;
serving as the  Dean  of  Students  from  1967  to  1968,  and  Dean  of
Instruction/Executive Dean from 1968 to 1975; and
  WHEREAS,  In  addition  to  earning  an  Associate in Arts degree from
Baltimore City Community College, President Steiner holds a Bachelor  of
Science  degree from the University of Maryland; Graduate Certificate in
Social Work from Florida State  University;  a  Master  of  Social  Work
degree  from  the  University  of Pennsylvania; a Juris Doctorate degree
from the University of Baltimore; a Master of Arts degree from  Columbia
University,  Teachers  College;  and  a  Doctor of Education degree from
Columbia University, Teachers College; and
  WHEREAS, A native of Baltimore, Maryland, President Steiner began  his
career  as  a  social  worker in 1959, working first as a caseworker and
later as director of Juvenile Court Services for the City of  Baltimore;
he  later  served  as  Director  of  Baltimore  Information and Referral
Services for the Health and Welfare Council  of  Metropolitan  Baltimore
and in 1963, became a member of the adjunct faculty of Community College
of Baltimore County; and
  WHEREAS, President Steiner's administrative skills and passion for the
needs  of  students  attracted  the attention of Dr. Alfred C. O'Connell
who, at the time, was serving as president of Harford Community  College
in Bel Air, Maryland; Dr. O'Connell named President Steiner as Harford's
Director  of  Admissions  and  Placement  in 1965; as Genesee's founding
president, one of Dr. O'Connell's first acts was  to  recruit  President
Steiner  for  the position of Dean of Students at the new college in New
York's Genesee County; and
  WHEREAS, Prior to being named President in 1975, President Steiner was
instrumental in recruiting and orienting Genesee's  first  students  and
played  a pivotal role in acquiring property on the east side of Batavia
for what is today, the Batavia Campus; and
  WHEREAS, As a result of President Steiner's highest  priority  of  the
development  of strong academic programs and services to students, Gene-
see Community College has reached record levels of enrollment; grown  to
offer  65  degrees  and  certificate  programs; and expanded the Batavia
Campus structure to include the Genesee Center for the Arts (1991),  the
Conable Technology Building (2000), the Humphrey Student Union (2005), a
new  art  gallery  presently  under  construction, a variety of exterior
athletic fields, and relocated the expanding School of  Nursing  to  the
new Med Tech Park business park; and
  WHEREAS,  In  recognition  of  President  Steiner's leadership and his
commitment to high-quality facilities, in 1991, the  Board  of  Trustees
named  the  theatre in the newly-constructed Genesee Center for the Arts
"The Stuart Steiner Theatre"; and

  WHEREAS, Many of President Steiner's historic  initiatives  have  made
higher  education  more  accessible to the region's residents, including
the development of one of the nation's first  off-site  campus  centers,
which  opened in Albion in 1990 with additional satellite campus centers
following  in Warsaw, Lakeville (and later Lima), Arcade, Dansville, and
Medina; the development of a comprehensive  distance  learning  program,
which enables more than 10 percent of Genesee students to participate in
online  courses;  the  Accelerated  College  Enrollment  Program,  which
enables more than 2,700 Western New York high school students to partic-
ipate in Genesee courses; and various  other  educational  and  training
programs and opportunities offered to the community; and
  WHEREAS,  President  Steiner has received countless state and national
recognitions for his work, including the New York State Phi Theta  Kappa
Service  Award,  the  New  York  State Community College Faculty Council
Distinguished Service Award, the Association of Community College  Trus-
tees  Northeast Region Chief Executive Officer Award, and the University
of Texas at Austin Community College Leadership Award; he was also named
a Transformational Leader in Higher Education by the W. K. Kellogg Foun-
dation; received  various  academic  honors  from  Columbia  University,
University  of  Pennsylvania,  University of Maryland, and University of
Baltimore Law School; and was named a distinguished alumnus of Baltimore
City Community College; and
  WHEREAS, President Steiner's service and record of innovation  led  to
numerous requests to serve on a variety of regional, state, and national
boards  and  committees  over  the years, including as a member and past
president of the New York State Association of Presidents  of  Community
Colleges; member of the New York State Education Commissioner's Advisory
Council  for  Higher Education; member of the Rochester Area Association
of Colleges; chair of a number of SUNY  panels  and  committees;  active
participant with the American Association of Community College's Commis-
sion;  chair  and/or  member of more than 20 Middle States Commission on
Higher Education accreditation teams, which make  college  accreditation
recommendations;  and  has  taken  on  various  other  sensitive special
assignments and appointments; and
  WHEREAS, President Steiner has mentored numerous  college  administra-
tors  and  professionals, including nearly 20 former Genesee vice presi-
dents and deans who have gone on  to  assume  positions  of  significant
leadership in higher education across the United States, and under Pres-
ident  Steiner's  influence, 105 members of Genesee's faculty and staff,
have received the prominent SUNY Chancellor's Awards for Excellence; and
  WHEREAS, Notable and nationally recognized publications  by  President
Steiner  include  THE PRAGMATIC PRESIDENCY (Community College Journal of
Research and Practice); THE COMMUNITY COLLEGE PRESIDENCY (Higher  Educa-
tion:  The  International  Journal  of  Higher Education and Educational
Planning); SUNY --  THE  "SYSTEMLESS"  SYSTEM  (Voices  of  Leadership);
COMMUNITY  COLLEGES  OF  THE NINETIES: LIVING ON THE FISCAL EDGE (Higher
Education in Turmoil: The Case of New York State and National  Prospects
for  Change);  he  also  edited  DISTANCE LEARNING: THE PRESIDENTS' TASK
FORCE REPORT, published by the State University of New York; and
  WHEREAS, The length and accomplishments of President Steiner's  presi-
dency  have  attracted  the attention of educational leaders from across
the nation and his tenure has been hailed by colleagues and  friends  as
one  of  the  most  extraordinary  community college presidencies in our
nation's history; and
  WHEREAS, President Steiner has worked tirelessly to bring  the  trans-
formative  power  of  education to many thousands in the Genesee-Living-
ston-Orleans-Wyoming region and beyond, and has done so while  maintain-

ing   Genesee's   reputation   as   one   of  the  most  affordable  and
cost-effective colleges within the State University system; and
  WHEREAS,  Rare indeed is the occurrence of such a compassionate blend-
ing of leadership, influence and  commitment  as  that  demonstrated  by
President  Stuart  Steiner over four decades of sacrifice and dedication
to others; now, therefore, be it
  RESOLVED, That this Legislative Body pause  in  its  deliberations  to
congratulate  President  Stuart Steiner upon the occasion of his retire-
ment; and be it further
  RESOLVED, That copies of this Resolution, suitably engrossed, be tran-
smitted to President Stuart Steiner.
